Award.AwardTitle: Step-Up to Physical Science and Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project provides scholarships to able and financially needy students majoring in physics, chemistry, environmental science, engineering, mathematics, and computer science. The project is implementing five new, sustainable support programs and services, and taking advantage of existing services to recruit, retain, and find jobs for more STEM majors. It is offering S-STEM scholarships of up to $6000 to each of two cohorts for their four years in college. A total of 25 students are benefiting from the scholarships, and many more students continue to benefit indefinitely from the added programs.

Intellectual Merit: The academic programs into which the students go are strong, and there are academic support activities. The programs are further transforming the college and its students. The project is studying the impact of these programs, and adjusting them to enhance what works and move away from what does not.

Broader Impact: The project is increasing the number and diversity of students who complete a STEM major and go on to work in the field or to further education. This project not only impacts the 25 scholars, but benefits all current and future STEM majors. Results are being disseminated through a website dedicated to the program, reported at national conferences, and published in national journals. This study benefits other colleges with aspirations to create more STEM majors, and strengthens the country's STEM infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Step-Up to Physical Science and Engineering at Randolph College (SUPER)
Peter Sheldon, Professor of Physics & Engineering and Director of Center for Student Research, PI

Randolph College is a nationally recognized, small, private liberal arts college in Lynchburg, Virginia. Randolph has a history of educating successful scientists and engineers, and the SUPER Program has helped to provide access to that excellent education and to more resources, for a larger and more diverse group of students.

Step-Up to Physical Science and Engineering at Randolph (SUPER) is a program that educates America?s future scientists and engineers. SUPER has been funded through the NSF S-STEM Program under Grant number DUE-1153997. Through the SUPER Program, we have developed support services which help make sure the student is doing everything they can to be a successful scientist. Outcomes include increased retention in STEM, increased numbers of STEM majors, and a larger number of STEM graduates entering the workforce.  

We developed five programs which have become models for other students and programs at the College and at other colleges. We developed a College Transition (Bridge) Program for new students, a system of enhanced support services, a First Year Seminar and Living-Learning Community, an Industry Mentor Program, and a four-year career plan. In addition, we place a significant emphasis on research and internship experiences.

We have targeted under-represented groups in the physical sciences, and have increased the number of applicants interested in science, have increased retention, have increased the number of majors in the sciences, and have seen great success upon graduation.

The NSF grant has helped four cohorts of students for the last five years. While the overall number of applicants to the College has significantly increased over the five years due to efforts in the enrollment division, we have increased the five-year average of 11% of applicants being interested in science to 20%. While the objective of this program was to recruit at least 25 scholars in two cohorts, we have recruited 100 SUPER scholars in four cohorts that were supported in part by the grant. The gender and ethnic diversity of the SUPER science scholars represents that of the College as a whole. Over the five years, we have tripled the number of physics and engineering majors (we have a physics major and a dual degree program in engineering), and nearly doubled the total number of science majors.

All graduates from the SUPER Program are employed or are in graduate school. 91% of graduates are doing something related to their science degree.

Further information on the SUPER program can be found at www.randolphscience.org.
